    A brief intro to the bayclumper

A brief intro to the bayclumper

Source: vignettes/bayclumper.Rmd
bayclumper.Rmd
library(bayclumpr)
library(rstan)
#> Loading required package: StanHeaders
#> Loading required package: ggplot2
#> rstan (Version 2.21.7, GitRev: 2e1f913d3ca3)
#> For execution on a local, multicore CPU with excess RAM we recommend calling
#> options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()).
#> To avoid recompilation of unchanged Stan programs, we recommend calling
#> rstan_options(auto_write = TRUE)
library(loo)
#> This is loo version 2.5.1
#> - Online documentation and vignettes at mc-stan.org/loo
#> - As of v2.0.0 loo defaults to 1 core but we recommend using as many as possible. Use the 'cores' argument or set options(mc.cores = NUM_CORES) for an entire session.
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'loo'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:rstan':
#> 
#>     loo

Generate a dataset

ds <- bayclumpr::sim.clumped(error = "S1", nobs = 50)
head(ds)
#>      x_TRUE Temperature    TempError    y_TRUE     D47error       D47 Material
#> 1  9.621020    9.634830  0.013809939 0.6197873  0.007716876 0.6275041        1
#> 2 11.294539   11.279160 -0.015379377 0.6913561 -0.005063469 0.6862926        1
#> 3 12.672824   12.677899  0.005074617 0.7368449  0.013163797 0.7500087        1
#> 4  9.145524    9.112516 -0.033008011 0.6076046  0.007528553 0.6151331        1
#> 5 12.515311   12.488494 -0.026817078 0.7325361  0.012718265 0.7452543        1
#> 6 12.101163   12.092546 -0.008617473 0.7150980  0.007602091 0.7227001        1

Fit a deming regression

simulateDeming(data = ds, replicates = 10)
#>        alpha       beta
#> 1  0.2610362 0.03757038
#> 2  0.2744925 0.03657942
#> 3  0.2632748 0.03736999
#> 4  0.2757392 0.03643825
#> 5  0.2771174 0.03630381
#> 6  0.2757809 0.03645119
#> 7  0.2554563 0.03807484
#> 8  0.2742689 0.03657743
#> 9  0.2605953 0.03763314
#> 10 0.2613174 0.03744631

Fit an OLS regression

simulateLM_measured(data = ds, replicates = 10)
#>        alpha       beta
#> 1  0.2807151 0.03581374
#> 2  0.2833936 0.03560239
#> 3  0.2721861 0.03652037
#> 4  0.2645816 0.03705486
#> 5  0.2655708 0.03699107
#> 6  0.2665814 0.03681482
#> 7  0.2659865 0.03688178
#> 8  0.2791944 0.03572168
#> 9  0.2687309 0.03668977
#> 10 0.2807427 0.03544070

Fit a weighted OLS

simulateLM_inverseweights(data = ds, replicates = 10)
#>        alpha       beta
#> 1  0.2581159 0.03769787
#> 2  0.2721114 0.03644095
#> 3  0.2704972 0.03652860
#> 4  0.2695121 0.03635264
#> 5  0.2728458 0.03638455
#> 6  0.2702042 0.03641683
#> 7  0.2744926 0.03621376
#> 8  0.2730909 0.03633564
#> 9  0.2701180 0.03658784
#> 10 0.2697856 0.03686051

Fit a York regression

simulateYork_measured(data = ds, replicates = 10)
#>        alpha       beta
#> 1  0.2604107 0.03765476
#> 2  0.2754831 0.03646564
#> 3  0.2526801 0.03829245
#> 4  0.2535957 0.03821676
#> 5  0.2650827 0.03729838
#> 6  0.2761390 0.03639921
#> 7  0.2647131 0.03733402
#> 8  0.2751992 0.03650266
#> 9  0.2724576 0.03675413
#> 10 0.2633915 0.03740793

Fit Bayesian models

BayesCal <- fitClumpedRegressions(calibrationData = ds, 
                                  numSavedSteps = 3000,
                                  priors = "Informative")

Predict for OLS model

paramdist <- simulateLM_measured(data = ds, replicates = 10)
recData <- data.frame(Sample = c("Sample 1", "Sample 2"), 
                      D47 = c(0.6, 0.7), 
                      D47error = c(0.005, 0.005))

predictTc(recData = recData, obCal = paramdist)
#>     Sample D47 D47error meanTemp    error
#> 1 Sample 1 0.6    0.005 59.74079 2.508955
#> 2 Sample 2 0.7    0.005 18.26387 1.687580

Predict based on Bayesian models

PredsBay <- BayesianPredictions(calModel = BayesCal$BLM1_fit,
                                recData = recData,
                                iter = 1000)

Results

PredsBay
